Member Of The
INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWSPAPER ASSOCIATION
Of Middle Atlantic States
Vol. XL—No. 25

ACTIVITY RULES
TO BE STRICT
ENFORCED NOW
Dean Berry Announces More
Stringent Observance Of
Old Rules
THREE FAILURES,
INFORMALS BASIS
Dean To Act Through Advisor, Advisory Committee,
Activity Head
Any student failing three courses,
or receiving in formals in three subjects absllutelty must resign from
all campus activitie, Dean Edward
W. Berry announced last week. This
rule has always been in effect but
is going to be enforced more stringently.
The Dean's office will be notified
of all failures, and through the adviser and the Dean's Advisory Committee, the activity head will be informed of all ineligible students.
Catalogue Gives Rules
Participation in students activities
is regulated by the following rules
accordng to the catalogue for 19351936:
"Probation: The dean may at any
time put on probabtion, any student
who falls behind in his work. Such
a student shall remain on probation
until relieved by the Dean.
"A student on 'probation may not
take part in any stpcient activlity
without special permission, and must
take to the Dean every two weeks
a report from each of his instructors, stating whether or not his work
during the preceding fortnight has
been satisfactory. If the report is
unsatisfactory, the student may be
suspended immediately from the
College.
"Student Activities in General:
Participation in the so-called activities of college life is restrcted to
students whose academic standing is
satisfactory. No student may be a
member of, or a candidate for, any
athletic team, musical or dramatic
club, debating team, or editorial
board: (a) during any year if he has
failed to complete satisfactorily the
preceding year's work, (b) if he has
been placed on proVation by the
Dean.
"Teams or Organizations Representing the University: No student
entering from another college shall
represent this College on any athletic team or in any student activity
durin his first term.
"The eligibility of other students
in their first year of residence shall
be determined by the Dean.
"A student following less than
three standard courses is not permitted to represent the University
on any team or in any student activity."

KAGAWA TALKS ABOUT
SOCIAL ISSUES AT CLUB
Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, noted Japanese evangelist, author, and lecturer, was the speaker at the fifth meeting of the University Supper Club
last evening at Levering Hall. An enthusiastic audience, which filled the
room, heard the "foremost Christian
of the world" discuss social problems
in his native land. After his address
here he proceeded to the Lyric Theatre, where he addressed a similarly
large crowd, concluding a two-day
stay in Baltimore, during which time
he made numerous addresses.
A convert to Christianity at fourteen, Dr. Kagawa, after studying two
years at the Theological Seminary in
his native city, Kobe, worked among
the poor in the slums. Ever a champion of the poor and downtrodden, the
charity worker wrote many books,
which succeeded in bringing the ruling class of Japan to their senses and
in gaining a name for himself. He
won his Bachelor of Divinity degree
at the Princeton Theological Seminary and was the native leader of the
Kingdom of God movement in Japan.
Devoting the royalties from his books
to uplifting the poor, he now holds a
high position on the Reconstruction
Commission of Japan.

JANUARY 22, 1936

INTERCOLLE GIA TS
(By Associated Collegiate Press)
New York—Predictions that intercollegiate football as it exists today
"will be dead in 1942" unless drastic
steps are taken immediately, and the
loudest furore in years over the perennial problems of athletic subsidization
and
spectator
drunkenness
marked the close of the hectic 1935
gridiron season.
Outstanding among 1935 developments was the forthright approval of
paid athletes by two big Southern
conferences, the Dixie and Southeastern. A marked tendency to follow
suit was noticeable all over the country.
The Dixie Conference voted that
room, board and tuition were no more
than an athlete ought to get for his
labors on the playing field, and
Southeastern made a sudden decision
in favor of above-board, athletic
scholarships. Despite the importance
of the move, little excitement was
evident in the comment that followed.
It was generally recognized that the
Southern schools were merely legalizing and admitting a common under-cover practice.
Blame for increased drunkenness
and rowdiness was laid squarely on
the shoulders of the colleges themselves. For incidents such as Dartmouth's twelfth man against Princeton, and the tearing down of the goal
posts before the completion of the
Princeton-Yale game, the schools
have themselves to blame, said such
outstanding footballers as Dr. Mal
Stevens of N. Y. U.; and the Board
of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals of the Methodist Episcopal
Church dealt itself a hand with the
statement that, "the leading teams

are invariably followed to the field
of battle by all of the barber shop
sports of their home environment, including the full roster of village idiots."
"Alumni" who flunked out of grade
school are blamed for most of the
disorders reaching a new peak this
season. "If we continue to accept
hoodlum dollars," said Mal Stevens,
"we ought to be willing to pay for
sufficient police protection."

The Faculty Cut
-1

The past week has been crowded
with hysterical rumors and frantic
prophecies congerning the standing

or whatever it is they get a year for
their job, to continue their studies.
The instructors are faculty members
of a few years' standing, usually
men who have settled down in Baltimore. They do a good deal of didactive work and have a vast amount
of academic promise. They have not
as yet the reputation that gives a
man his choice of positions so that
the chances of their securing places
elsewhere are slim.
If these men are dropped, their
work will have to be taken over by
the surviving members of the faculty
--those men who are now doing, :n
general, little teaching and much research. If they spend more time with
undergraduates, they will have to
spend less time with graduate students and their own researches. This
has been cited as a gain for the Undergraduates-something that they,
who pay about the highest college
tuition in the country, have been
clamoring for.
We are not so sure that the majority of undergraduates would rather merely be in the same lecture room
with a professor of some reputation
or have personal instruction from the
brilliant younger faculty minds. Perhaps, by a reapportionment of time.
a mean can be reached whereby the
"name" men can give a little more
undergraduate courses and take a
little time of their own for investigations, and the younger men can be
freed from some of their instructing
and allowed more time for research.
This, however, solves no financial
problem.
Other plans have been suggested
as alternatives to that of getting rid
of the up-and-coming faculty members. One is to cut the salaries of
enough of the better paid men to accomplish a saving of $40,000. Having
already taken a 10 per cent cut, most
of the professors are against this.
Some say they would leave if that
were done. Some are leaving anyway.
In any case, while there is a deficit, the University can not spend the
money it should. The important thing
is for the University to get funds.
Certainly there is no inducement for
anybody to support the University
financially when the older men announce that they are resigning and
the University announces that it is
firing the younger men. Those men
who are contemplating resigning will
have a hard time finding a place
where they can enjoy the same academic freedom they had at 'the Hopkins.

epilogue states unequivocally: "Bah,

CRASH!
IT's a thunderstorm sweeping over Pittsfield,
Massachusetts. But G-E engineers, instead
of hiding under the bed, go up on the roof to
be nearer the lightning. On one of the buildings
of the Pittsfield Works they have built and
evipped a lightning observatory. By means of
an ingenious periscope and a high-speed,
motor-driven camera, any lightning flash
occurring within many miles—north, south,
cast, or west—can be automatically photographed. Its characteristics, as recorded on
the film, can then be compared with those
of the artificial flashes produced by the
10,000,000-volt lightning generator in the
laboratory.
An observatory has to have a hole in the roof.
To keep the rain from falling on the 12 lenses
of the camera—and from running down the
engineers' necks—compressed air is blown
upward through the aperture. When next the
thunder rolls over the Berkshires, and timid
citizens are cowering under the bedclothes,
these G-E engineers will be up on the roof
taking notes on Jove's own brand of lightning.

It takes 25 operations

EACH Ford valve requires
twenty-five separate operations from the time work starts
on a rough valve until it is
ready for use. That is a surprising number of operations
for such a simple looking
part, but typical of Ford care
in manufacturing.
The stems of the rough
valves first receive .two preliminary grinding operations.
Then they go through a furnace where the heads are
brought to a red heat. Next,
automatic fingers place them
in a huge machine where a
ram strikes the red-hot heads.
This operation refines the
grain structure in the head,
straightens it, and forms the
valve seat.
Valves then pass through
other grinding, machining and

Repeating their feat of a month
ago, much more disastrously, however, the Washington College quintet ran rampant over the Homewood
aggregation by a score of 42-2 at
Chestertown. The Jays attempted, by
spasmodic scoring, to overcome the
strong first period lead of the Shoremen but the opposition ovevrpoweled
them scoring 22 points, to 16 for
the visitors during the last half.
Opening with a fast first quarter
exchange of shots, the game soon
settled down, and the superiority of
the home team was in evidence from
that point on. Th contest was dull
in spots, interest being only awakened when the Mallonee Machine
tried to break through the brilliant
Hopkins
defense of the leaders.

showed that they can be depended
upon to aid in pinches. In spite of
the inflow of fresh material, the
Washington courtmen steam-rolled
to a 42-23 triumqth.

was Zebrowski, giant Shoreman center, who counted for 18 points. Huffman, a teammate, was runnerup with

ACTIVITY RULES
TO BE STRICT
ENFORCED NOW
Dean Berry Announces More
Stringent Observance Of
Old Rules
THREE FAILURES,
INFORMALS BASIS
Dean To Act Through Advisor, Advisory Committee,
Activity Head
Any student failing three courses,
or receiving in formals in three subjects absllutelty must resign from
all campus activitie, Dean Edward
W. Berry announced last week. This
rule has always been in effect but
is going to be enforced more stringently.
The Dean's office will be notified
of all failures, and through the adviser and the Dean's Advisory Committee, the activity head will be informed of all ineligible students.
Catalogue Gives Rules
Participation in students activities
is regulated by the following rules
accordng to the catalogue for 19351936:
"Probation: The dean may at any
time put on probabtion, any student
who falls behind in his work. Such
a student shall remain on probation
until relieved by the Dean.
"A student on 'probation may not
take part in any stpcient activlity
without special permission, and must
take to the Dean every two weeks
a report from each of his instructors, stating whether or not his work
during the preceding fortnight has
been satisfactory. If the report is
unsatisfactory, the student may be
suspended immediately from the
College.
"Student Activities in General:
Participation in the so-called activities of college life is restrcted to
students whose academic standing is
satisfactory. No student may be a
member of, or a candidate for, any
athletic team, musical or dramatic
club, debating team, or editorial
board: (a) during any year if he has
failed to complete satisfactorily the
preceding year's work, (b) if he has
been placed on proVation by the
Dean.
"Teams or Organizations Representing the University: No student
entering from another college shall
represent this College on any athletic team or in any student activity
durin his first term.
"The eligibility of other students
in their first year of residence shall
be determined by the Dean.
"A student following less than
three standard courses is not permitted to represent the University
on any team or in any student activity."

KAGAWA TALKS ABOUT
SOCIAL ISSUES AT CLUB
Dr. Toyohiko Kagawa, noted Japanese evangelist, author, and lecturer, was the speaker at the fifth meeting of the University Supper Club
last evening at Levering Hall. An enthusiastic audience, which filled the
room, heard the "foremost Christian
of the world" discuss social problems
in his native land. After his address
here he proceeded to the Lyric Theatre, where he addressed a similarly
large crowd, concluding a two-day
stay in Baltimore, during which time
he made numerous addresses.
A convert to Christianity at fourteen, Dr. Kagawa, after studying two
years at the Theological Seminary in
his native city, Kobe, worked among
the poor in the slums. Ever a champion of the poor and downtrodden, the
charity worker wrote many books,
which succeeded in bringing the ruling class of Japan to their senses and
in gaining a name for himself. He
won his Bachelor of Divinity degree
at the Princeton Theological Seminary and was the native leader of the
Kingdom of God movement in Japan.
Devoting the royalties from his books
to uplifting the poor, he now holds a
high position on the Reconstruction
Commission of Japan.

cities and towns the American people would lose that curious quality

JANUARY 22, 1936

INTERCOLLE GIA TS
(By Associated Collegiate Press)
New York—Predictions that intercollegiate football as it exists today
"will be dead in 1942" unless drastic
steps are taken immediately, and the
loudest furore in years over the perennial problems of athletic subsidization
and
spectator
drunkenness
marked the close of the hectic 1935
gridiron season.
Outstanding among 1935 developments was the forthright approval of
paid athletes by two big Southern
conferences, the Dixie and Southeastern. A marked tendency to follow
suit was noticeable all over the country.
The Dixie Conference voted that
room, board and tuition were no more
than an athlete ought to get for his
labors on the playing field, and
Southeastern made a sudden decision
in favor of above-board, athletic
scholarships. Despite the importance
of the move, little excitement was
evident in the comment that followed.
It was generally recognized that the
Southern schools were merely legalizing and admitting a common under-cover practice.
Blame for increased drunkenness
and rowdiness was laid squarely on
the shoulders of the colleges themselves. For incidents such as Dartmouth's twelfth man against Princeton, and the tearing down of the goal
posts before the completion of the
Princeton-Yale game, the schools
have themselves to blame, said such
outstanding footballers as Dr. Mal
Stevens of N. Y. U.; and the Board
of Temperance, Prohibition and Public Morals of the Methodist Episcopal
Church dealt itself a hand with the
statement that, "the leading teams

are invariably followed to the field
of battle by all of the barber shop
sports of their home environment, including the full roster of village idiots."
"Alumni" who flunked out of grade
school are blamed for most of the
disorders reaching a new peak this
season. "If we continue to accept
hoodlum dollars," said Mal Stevens,
"we ought to be willing to pay for
sufficient police protection."

The Faculty Cut
-1

The past week has been crowded
with hysterical rumors and frantic
prophecies congerning the standing

or whatever it is they get a year for
their job, to continue their studies.
The instructors are faculty members
of a few years' standing, usually
men who have settled down in Baltimore. They do a good deal of didactive work and have a vast amount
of academic promise. They have not
as yet the reputation that gives a
man his choice of positions so that
the chances of their securing places
elsewhere are slim.
If these men are dropped, their
work will have to be taken over by
the surviving members of the faculty
--those men who are now doing, :n
general, little teaching and much research. If they spend more time with
undergraduates, they will have to
spend less time with graduate students and their own researches. This
has been cited as a gain for the Undergraduates-something that they,
who pay about the highest college
tuition in the country, have been
clamoring for.
We are not so sure that the majority of undergraduates would rather merely be in the same lecture room
with a professor of some reputation
or have personal instruction from the
brilliant younger faculty minds. Perhaps, by a reapportionment of time.
a mean can be reached whereby the
"name" men can give a little more
undergraduate courses and take a
little time of their own for investigations, and the younger men can be
freed from some of their instructing
and allowed more time for research.
This, however, solves no financial
problem.
Other plans have been suggested
as alternatives to that of getting rid
of the up-and-coming faculty members. One is to cut the salaries of
enough of the better paid men to accomplish a saving of $40,000. Having
already taken a 10 per cent cut, most
of the professors are against this.
Some say they would leave if that
were done. Some are leaving anyway.
In any case, while there is a deficit, the University can not spend the
money it should. The important thing
is for the University to get funds.
Certainly there is no inducement for
anybody to support the University
financially when the older men announce that they are resigning and
the University announces that it is
firing the younger men. Those men
who are contemplating resigning will
have a hard time finding a place
where they can enjoy the same academic freedom they had at 'the Hopkins.

In the first ten days since its publication, no book in recent years was
so much discussed nor so highly

Much will probably be said of the
right the author has to call his book
a novel. It has no plot worth mentioning; it is purely a personal narrative, a biography. But it is a story,
full of the drama of human life-"a tale of sad life", as the author
says, in the line which sets the mood
and atmosphere for the entire book.
There is even some semblance of an
abortive love story; but, beyond the
fact that Oliver is not the type for
love, except as duty requires, the
epilogue states unequivocally: "Bah,
there are love stories enough in the
bookstalls for those who like them."
The Last Puritan contains no dialogue—in the modern sense. Every
character but one speaks in Mr. Santayana's inspired language, in his
poetical eloquence. But the author
justifies himself:

Th,_: story of this novel-without-aplot concerns one Oliver Alden, a
young, intelligent, and handsome
Puritan, in whom "Puritanism worked itself out to its logical end," who
"convinced hmself on Puritan grounds
that it was wrong to be a Puritan
. . . and remained a Puritan notwithstanding. Oliver was a perfect
synthesis of varied backgrounds -all culminating in the tragedy of the
ultimate Puritan. His was a moral
nature, burdened and over-strung,
and a critical faculty "fearless but
helplessly subjective."
In antithesis to Oliver Alden, there
is his closest friend Lord Jim,
the captain of, his father's yacht.
Lord Jim is the typical romantic
cavalier with an extra dash of the
pagan. To Oliver, he represents all
that Oliver is not—the personifies
freedom and frankness; he loves the
world and drinks deep from the cup
of life, enjoying it fully and living
it with all, his might. Lord Jim exerted a great influence on Oliver Alden's life.

CRASH!
IT's a thunderstorm sweeping over Pittsfield,
Massachusetts. But G-E engineers, instead
of hiding under the bed, go up on the roof to
be nearer the lightning. On one of the buildings
of the Pittsfield Works they have built and
evipped a lightning observatory. By means of
an ingenious periscope and a high-speed,
motor-driven camera, any lightning flash
occurring within many miles—north, south,
cast, or west—can be automatically photographed. Its characteristics, as recorded on
the film, can then be compared with those
of the artificial flashes produced by the
10,000,000-volt lightning generator in the
laboratory.
An observatory has to have a hole in the roof.
To keep the rain from falling on the 12 lenses
of the camera—and from running down the
engineers' necks—compressed air is blown
upward through the aperture. When next the
thunder rolls over the Berkshires, and timid
citizens are cowering under the bedclothes,
these G-E engineers will be up on the roof
taking notes on Jove's own brand of lightning.

sleeper, of lesser climbing prowess, has tried
throwing shoes and hair brushes at the offending light. Now there is hope that this war will
soon be over.
Adequate street lighting is, of course, a necessity. G-E illumination engineers have perfected
a new fixture that directs the light where it is
needed—on the street—and keeps it front
trespassinff on the pillow. A concealed light
source '
and a reflector designed along new
optical lines have removed street lamps from
the list of public enemies of sleep.

It takes 25 operations
to finish one Ford valve
EACH Ford valve requires
twenty-five separate operations from the time work starts
on a rough valve until it is
ready for use. That is a surprising number of operations
for such a simple looking
part, but typical of Ford care
in manufacturing.
The stems of the rough
valves first receive .two preliminary grinding operations.
Then they go through a furnace where the heads are
brought to a red heat. Next,
automatic fingers place them
in a huge machine where a
ram strikes the red-hot heads.
This operation refines the
grain structure in the head,
straightens it, and forms the
valve seat.
Valves then pass through
other grinding, machining and

constant check.
In spite of this care, each
Ford valve is subjected to
rigid final inspection. Amplifying gages check the stem
for roundness within two tenthousandths of an inch. Similar gages check diameter.
Other inspection equipment indicates the slightest
run out" of seat and checks
stem end for squareness. Then
the valves go into a constant
temperature room where they
are inspected for length.
